Morality has two principal meanings:
 
Morality has two principal meanings:
−
* In its "descriptive" sense, ''morality'' refers to [[Value (personal and cultural)|personal or cultural values]], [[code of conduct|codes of conduct]] or social [[mores]]. Describing morality in this way is not making a claim about what is objectively right or wrong, but only referring to what is considered right or wrong by an individual or some group of [[people]] (such as a religion). This sense of the term is addressed by [[descriptive ethics]].
+
* In its [[descriptive ethics|"descriptive"]] sense, ''morality'' refers to [[Value (personal and cultural)|personal or cultural values]], [[code of conduct|codes of conduct]] or social [[mores]]. It does connote objective claims of right or wrong, but only refers to that which is considered right or wrong. [[Descriptive ethics]] is the study of definitions of morality.
−
* In its "[[normative]]" sense, ''morality'' is a [[definition]] of right and wrong which excludes [[subjective]] opinion. It could be defined as ideal conduct. This usage of the term is characterized by "definitive" statements such as "That person ''is'' [[Moral responsibility|morally responsible]]" rather than descriptive statements like "Many people believe that person is morally responsible." These ideas are explored in [[normative ethics]]. The normative sense of morality is often challenged by [[moral nihilism]] (which rejects the existence of any moral truths)<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gert|first=Bernard|title=The Definition of Morality|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Fall 2008 Edition) Edward N. Zalta (ed.)|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, CSLI, Stanford University|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2008/entries/morality-definition/|accessdate=January 28, 2011}}</ref> and supported by [[moral realism]] (which supports the existence of moral truths).
+
* In its "[[normative]]" sense, ''morality'' is a [[definition]] of right and wrong which excludes [[subjective]] opinion. [[Normative ethics]] is the branch of philosophy concerned with correctly choosing between such definitions.
